user.biography:
Rescue, education, & advocacy for farm animals. 
🐄🐖🐐🐑🐓🦃

node.text:
Henrietta, our Acton Sanctuary’s eldest turkey, may seem sassy and brash, strutting around the aviary like she owns the place. But beneath that tough exterior, she’s a motherly figure—and now grandmotherly!—to our smallest chickens.

The meat industry changed how these turkeys live and grow, but they’ll never change who they are: flock-oriented, social creatures who thrive with love.

This #MothersDay, gift compassion. For a one-time $35 donation, you can “adopt” Henrietta. In thanks, we’ll send you a digital certificate featuring this outspoken yet loyal grandmother. You can print this certificate for yourself, email it to a “Henrietta” in your life, or pass it along to anyone who could use a little extra love and care this time of year. Tap the link in our bio to adopt. 💚

node.title: Henrietta: Grandmotherly Turkey to Her Flock of Orphaned Chickens

node.text:
At his 2020 Oscars acceptance, Joaquin Phoenix spoke to the plight of mother cows and their babies. A day later, he helped liberate a calf and her mother from a Los Angeles slaughterhouse and brought them to Farm Sanctuary.

When Phoenix first met Liberty and Indigo (as they'd soon be named), he experienced them as beings in the grip of uncontrollable fear. Liberty had been trucked from a feedlot to the slaughterhouse where she gave birth. They were exhausted, dehydrated, and frightened.

Almost a year later, though, Phoenix got the chance to meet them as individuals. As Liberty and Indigo: warm, intelligent beings with their own unique lives, as animals experiencing autonomy and with the freedom to exhibit their natural behavior.

Phoenix reflected on the rescue and the environmental realities we're facing today: “We spend one day each year paying homage to our planet, Earth Day, but the other 364 days, we consume with impunity,” he said. “It's undeniable the detrimental impact that animal agriculture has on the environment. This simple act of rescuing Liberty and Indigo...in some ways, it's just as simple as sparing the lives of these creatures. But it's also an acknowledgment of not only the destruction they feel at our hands but the environment as a whole. By our actions, we either have the choice to continue to destroy other beings and the environment, or we begin the process of reversing the damage that we've done.”

With more than nine billion animals raised and slaughtered for human consumption each year in the U.S. alone, modern animal agriculture puts an incredible strain on natural resources such as land, water, and fossil fuel.

Climate change is imminent if we do not adopt a plant-based lifestyle. Every day is #EarthDay.

Special thanks to @LAAnimalSave for making the Liberty and Indigo rescue possible, and to filmmaker Shaun Monson (@EarthlingsFilm) for this beautiful piece.

node.title: Joaquin Phoenix Reunited with Rescued Mother Cow & Calf for Earth Day

node.text:
Emmett and Wyatt have been through a lot together. As youngsters, they lived on a derelict farm, where more than 80 pigs were strewn across the property in dark, cramped, and waste-filled barns, trailers, and sheds. 

More than three years later, they remain inseparable, whether rooting through their pasture by day or snuggling close at bedtime. It's not too late to participate in our Valentine's Day special and sponsor this loving pair for a one-time donation of $35—tap the link in our bio!

PS: Our special #ValentinesDay event is LIVE! Tune in for a behind-the-scenes look at our Sanctuaries and to hear from special guests who are spreading love in their communities. Tap the link in our bio!

node.title: Pig Pals Help Each Other Heal From Trauma

node.text:
Bella and Vector remind us of twins separated at birth. They look almost exactly alike, and both have severe cross beak—a condition that impairs their ability to eat. They share meals, groom each other, and snuggle up together to sleep. They are truly better together. 💞

Tap the link in our bio to sponsor these love birds for #ValentinesDay!

node.title: A Pair Of Hens With Cross Beak Find Love In One Another

node.text:
Squid and Otto found friendship after they were each rescued from meat production. Both boys were too sick to be profitable: Otto can’t eat on his own, and Squid has permanent damage from a broken leg.

As a special #ValentinesDay opportunity, you can “adopt” these spunky lambs through our Adopt a Farm Animal Program—tap the link in our bio! 💕

node.title: Two Lambs With Special Needs Find Friendship at Farm Sanctuary

node.text: For 35 years, we’ve been fighting the disastrous effects of animal agriculture on the planet, our communities, agricultural workers, and billions of farmed animals. Through the new FarmSanctuary.org, we're giving more people access to the information and tools necessary to keep our mission going and growing. Explore this new resource and join us in the pursuit of bold solutions to end animal agriculture and foster just and compassionate vegan living. 💚
One thing we can say for sure about caring for farm animals is that it's never boring! Here's a behind-the-scenes look at Farm Sanctuary life:

While 2020 has kept us six feet apart (and often further) from our family and friends, our Farm Sanctuary community has grown even closer—thanks to you.

Even in challenging times, you continued to prioritize our lifesaving work. United in compassion, we rescued and provided refuge to animals in need while keeping our nearly 1,000 rescued residents safe and well this year. And even though you weren’t able to be here at our Sanctuaries, your energy and enthusiasm were still felt by all of us—human and nonhuman alike.

Take a look at our year in review:

"I think that by saying 'I'm not going to eat turkey this year,' it means I am taking a stand to be on the side of making change ... and saying, actually, I don't want to contribute to climate change. Actually, I don't want to hurt animals."

@aliciasilverstone and her son Bear Blu show us what it means to them to have a turkey-free Thanksgiving. 🦃💚

node.title: Alicia Silverstone & Her Son Bear Blu Celebrate a Turkey-free Thanksgiving

node.text:
Happy #FathersDay to all of the dads out there! 💚

Celebrate with us by watching Leo, an orphaned calf on the brink of death, be welcomed into his new adopted family—a herd of enormous steers.

node.title: Tiny Orphan Calf Adopted By a Herd of Steers

node.text:
Some words from Joaquin Phoenix: ⁣
⁣
“You might remember, a few months ago, I helped rescue a cow and her newborn baby calf. ⁣
⁣
Liberty was pregnant when she was set to be slaughtered. An incredible set of circumstances including the birth of her calf and a slaughterhouse owner’s refusal to separate a mother from her baby, led to this beautiful pair being rescued by @LAAnimalSave and @FarmSanctuary.⁣
⁣
It’s impossible not to smile at the love that radiates from Liberty for her calf, Indigo, or the marvelous curiosity they share for their new life roaming spacious land in permanent sanctuary. Thanks to generous supporters like you, Liberty is able to nurse Indigo, bond with her, protect her, and watch her grow up — just as nature intended.⁣
⁣
Although we cannot rescue our way out of animal agriculture, I hope you will always know Liberty and Indigo as living embodiments of liberation and as ambassadors for a compassionate vegan lifestyle."⁣
⁣
In celebration of Liberty's first #MothersDay at Farm Sanctuary, for a one-time donation, you can symbolically adopt the pair today. Tap the link in our bio.

By meeting cruelty with kindness, making changes towards a plant-based lifestyle (and encouraging others to do the same!), and treating all beings with respect, we all demonstrate the power of Sanctuary.

Thank you for helping us add momentum to a growing movement to create a better world for farm animals. 💚

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Farm Sanctuary on August 24, 2021. May be an image of animal, outdoors and text that says 'farm sanctuary'.

node.text:
10 years ago today, we rescued Orlando from a fetid barn where he was underweight, dehydrated, and sick.
 
He'd been purchased at auction, along with 10 other calves, for cheap beef production (while Orlando, a Holstein, is a dairy breed, the males are often raised for beef or veal since they can't produce milk). When the group became sick, however, their owner denied them care—instead opting to shoot them, one by one.

By the time authorities intervened, only 5 (including Orlando) of the original 11 remained.  We got them the lifesaving care they needed and brought the youngsters home to Farm Sanctuary. 

Today, Orlando is a big, strong, yet goofy gentle giant who loves his herd and his human friends—and we love him right back. Swipe 👉 to see him now!

node.text:
June B. Free (right) and Susan are finding peace and comfort in one another as they adjust to life at our Acton Sanctuary. In case you missed it, these brave cows were among the group of 40 who escaped from an LA slaughterhouse in June—and are the only two to have survived.

The cows are understandably wary after everything they've been through. Our team is giving them plenty of space to decompress—and they're finding peace among one another. Cows are herd animals, so having a friend is crucial to the girls' wellbeing. Once they settle in a little bit more, we'll be able to conduct the proper medical checks for clearance into the larger herd.

The pair may never warm up to us fully, but that's okay—Sanctuary is for them, not for us. We don't force animals to like or spend time with people. It's a space for them to live as they please. And for the first time in their lives, June and Susan are loved and protected and can live without fear of slaughter.

node.text:
The facts of the dairy industry are cruel, and the cycle will continue as long as we continue consuming dairy products. But as plant-based milk goes increasingly mainstream, it’s getting easier than ever to find oat, soy, almond, hemp, and pea milk in both large chain stores and smaller neighborhood shops.⁣
⁣
Tap the link in our bio to choose a new milk. #WorldPlantMilkDay

node.text: When people visit Farm Sanctuary, they're often most intrigued by the traits and behaviors of chickens like Duemie. Perhaps because the word “chicken” so often refers to food rather than a living being, visitors are surprised by chickens’ strong personalities, their ability to form friendships, and their capacity for curiosity. 💚

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Farm Sanctuary on August 20, 2021.
Photo by Farm Sanctuary on August 18, 2021. May be an image of animal and outdoors.

node.text:
We love these recent photos of former Farm Sanctuary residents Lenny and Freddie, who have been inseparable ever since they met each other one year ago today!⁣
⁣
The Jersey and Ayrshire calves were born around the same time—each at separate dairy farms in New York State. Since male cows can’t make milk, their farmers didn’t want them. Sadly, most “dairy boys” are either culled immediately, or raised and slaughtered for veal or cheap beef. Luckily, Lenny and Freddie's rescuers helped them get to Farm Sanctuary instead.⁣
⁣
Now, these friends are living the sanctuary life at @peacefield.farm—part of our Farm Animal Adoption Network. Because our Sanctuaries are often at capacity, we depend on the compassionate adopters in our network who are willing and able to make a direct difference for farm animals in need. ⁣
⁣
Thank you, Peacefield, for giving these boys (and all the rescued farm animals in your care) such beautiful lives!⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Photos: Peacefield

node.text:
When we first met Bellamy, she was laying in a ditch, covered with deep, maggot-infested wounds, fighting for her survival.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
A local animal control agency had called us earlier that day, alerting us to the calf who’d reportedly been on the loose for days. We rushed to the scene and worked quickly to load her into the trailer and transport her to the veterinary hospital.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Although Bellamy was weak, thin, and very sick, she responded well to treatment and pulled through enough to come home to our New York Sanctuary. She was nervous and shy when she first arrived but everything changed when she met the herd—her new family—for the first time.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
We can’t be sure where Bellamy came from before she ended up in the ditch but, based on her breed, she was likely being raised for beef. All every farm animal wants is to breathe fresh air and feel the sun on their faces. For Bellamy, this chance at freedom nearly took her life, but we’re so glad she’s here experiencing it four years later.

Photo by Farm Sanctuary on August 17, 2021. May be an image of animal, grass and text that says 'BEFORE farm sanctuary'.

node.text:
Ari was born at a “cull sale". Dairy cows, who produce milk only when they're pregnant or nursing, are subjected to a relentless cycle of gestation, birth, and insemination until their bodies are worn out. At four or five years old, these “spent” cows are brought to auction and sold for cheap beef.⁣
⁣
When Ari’s mother gave birth in a sale house, workers promptly drove her to the auction floor before she even had a chance to clean her newborn. Ari, only minutes old, was left on the floor to die. Luckily, a horse rescue was there monitoring conditions of horses sent to be sold for meat. A member of their party passed the empty pen and saw what she thought was a jacket, but turned out to be Ari.⁣
⁣
Thanks to the compassion of this woman, we rushed Ari to the veterinary hospital to receive vital care, then brought him home to our New York Sanctuary. With lots of heart and lots of help, Ari made it out of the woods and began to thrive. ⁣
⁣
Now, eight years later, Ari is a strong and active member of our main herd (swipe 👉 to the end to see him now!). He reminds us every day that farm human animals are here with us, not for us. Happy rescue anniversary, Ari.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Farm Sanctuary on August 14, 2021. May be an image of animal and text that says 'farm sanctuary'.
Photo by Farm Sanctuary on August 14, 2021. May be an image of animal, outdoors and text that says 'farm sanctuary'.
Photo by Farm Sanctuary on August 14, 2021. May be an image of animal and text that says 'farm sanctuary'.

node.text:
Boris, a former "Easter lamb", was set to be slaughtered at just four months old. His life took a different turn, however, when a kind rescuer named Tess saw him as an individual—not a meal.⁣
⁣
Tess brought Boris home to live with her. The tiny lamb loved playing with her two dogs and enjoyed regular bottle feedings from his new adoptive mom. But as Boris grew older, Tess knew he needed something she couldn’t provide: a flock to keep him company. So, she reached out to us for help.⁣
⁣
We welcomed the boisterous youngster to our New York Sanctuary (two years ago today!) for a temporary stay before connecting him with his loving forever home at @kindredspiritssanctuary in Florida. Adoption is a crucial part of our work; we wouldn’t be able to save nearly as many sick, injured, and ailing farm animals without our Farm Animal Adoption Network members. But no matter where they go, animals like Boris will always be extended members of the Farm Sanctuary family!

node.text:
NEW RESCUE: Meet Norman! Last week, we welcomed the nine-year-old steer to our New York Sanctuary. He was previously being cared for as a companion, along with horses and a goat, but his guardian’s situation changed and they needed to find new homes for their animals. Norman’s friends were being rehomed elsewhere, and since cows are herd animals, he needed companionship.⁣
⁣
Norman is friendly, charming, and quick to win over the hearts of everyone he meets. He’ll make a great fit for our special needs herd (a gentler crowd for an older steer like him) once he’s completed a routine quarantine period. Welcome home, Norman!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Farm Sanctuary on August 12, 2021. May be an image of animal and outdoors.
Photo by Farm Sanctuary on August 12, 2021. May be an image of animal and grass.

node.text:
MICKEY UPDATE: This little lamb is growing up! Even though he struggled to stand or walk when he was born, Mickey has been gaining strength and mobility in his legs. He recently joined a barn with Holly sheep and Sadie goat, who are gentler animals for him to be around since they each have mobility challenges of their own. ⁣
⁣
Mickey's loving the extra company and the chance to just be a lamb—something he would’ve never experienced in animal agriculture. In fact, of the two million sheep slaughtered in the U.S. every year, over 90% are between six and eight months old because consumers prefer meat from lambs. We're so grateful Mickey's former guardians chose sanctuary over slaughter, giving him the all-too-rare opportunity to live a full life.

Photo by Farm Sanctuary on August 11, 2021. May be an image of animal, outdoors and text that says 'farm sanctuary'.

node.text: Missy loves belly rubs, treats, and attention. Emotionally sensitive, playful, and inquisitive, pigs like her aren't so different from the companion animals we share our homes with.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Farm Sanctuary on August 10, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, animal, food and outdoors.

node.text: We can't believe it's already been one year since we welcomed Bitsy to our New York Sanctuary! This sweet pig came to us after her previous guardian passed away, and since his family was unable to continue caring for her, they reached out to us. Even though her guardian’s siblings had purchased and slaughtered some pigs in the past, they found they could no longer bring themselves to do so and honored his decision to keep this pig as a companion. Thanks to their incredible compassion, she’ll spend the rest of her life in the freedom of sanctuary.
